item.description:
The familiar saying “We are what we eat” can certainly apply to more than our physical state of wellness. Is diet a mirror of...well, is it a mirror of something more than taste or cultural conditioning? Dietary restrictions in one form or the other are common to many religions. The Jewish and Muslim religions prohibit the eating of pork. Jewish dietary laws also prohibit the mixing of dairy and meat in the same meal. Both the Muslim and Mormon faiths prohibit the drinking of alcoholic beverages, and Mormonism also prohibits the drinking of coffee and teas. Some Buddhist sects are vegetarian, as is the Seventh Day Adventist Christian denomination. And there are, I’m sure, many other religious dietary restrictions of which I am quite ignorant. (If there are any errors in the above, please accept my apologies and let me know so that I can correct my statement. Although, the remark about my ignorance is not debatable).

But the ethics of diet goes far beyond religious restriction. The environmental health and the personal health of dietary choices are issues of world significance. If diet can make you sick, then your bad choices increase heath care costs, and also touch upon the ethical significance of trying to stay healthy. And if eating meat, for example, expends about ten times as much energy as grains and other vegetables to produce, and destroys forested areas that produce environmental havoc, it is a vital ethical issue as well. So spiritual issues aside, dietary choices  may be one the most significant class of choices that a person may make. And what about the spiritual implications of diet? If there are spiritual implications, what are they? As someone coming from a vegetarian perspective I would like to quote Schopenhauer: "The assumption that animals are without rights and the illusion that our treatment of them has no moral significance is a positively outrageous example of Western crudity and barbarity. Universal compassion is the only guarantee of morality." (ref. http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ar...)

The meat eaters may not become vegetarians after this discussion, and the vegetarians are not likely to go running for a Big Mack, but in this discussion we might just edge closer to an understanding that goes beyond the mere advancement of a particular agenda. And we may learn something about the diversity of dietary choice that, by increasing the depth of perspective we may increase the understanding of each others' religious, spiritual and philosophical points of view. As with all of our conversations, mutual respect for our various points of view is required.
